Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2020 21st ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports students at US institutions to attend the Twenty-first Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile). The HotMobile workshop will be held in Austin, TX, March 3-4, 2020. HotMobile is a workshop targeting mobile computing and system integration fields. Attending this event will benefit the scientific progress of a student's research. The workshop discusses fundamental open questions, advocates new approaches, offers constructive critiques of the state-of-the-art, debunks existing assumptions, reports unexpected early results, reports on promising but unproven ideas, or proposes new evaluation methods. The exposure to the technical content of HotMobile will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields, with a long-term benefit of scientific advances in mobile computing.

Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending this workshop but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, applications from female and underrepresented groups in mobile computing research will be strongly encouraged. Up to 25 students will receive travel grants from this award to attend HotMobile.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
HotMobile 2020 provides a high caliber forum to present innovative and significant research on the design, implementation, usage, and evaluation of mobile systems, applications, and services. HotMobile seeks papers that focus primarily on systems and applications and propose new directions of research, advocate non-traditional approaches to old (or new) ideas, or generate controversy and discussion. The workshop especially encourages papers that identify fundamental open questions, advocate a new approach, offer a constructive critique of the state-of-the-art, debunk existing assumptions, report unexpected early results, report on promising but unproven ideas, or propose new evaluation methods. The research and development results reported in HotMobile workshops span multiple disciplines, including wireless communication, mobile applications, wearable computing, vehicular wireless systems, personal area networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, data management, scheduling, sensors, security and privacy. HotMobile seeks to provide a cross-disciplinary venue for researchers addressing the design of mobile computing in the context of an integrated system. The 2020 workshop will carry on the tradition that the HotMobile workshop series has established as the premiere workshop on mobile computing.

Need for student travel support: We are hoping to fund around 25 students traveling to the workshop. We have worked diligently with the hotel to negotiate a reasonable nightly rate to minimize the cost for attendees.  Given the accommodation cost, it is expected that the total expenses per student to attend HotMobile 2020, including airfare, will easily exceed $1100. When factoring in the student registration fee, together with the typical travel and lodging costs associated with attending a workshop, will impose a hardship on many students and/or their faculty advisors. Hence, we seek funding to help offset these costs.


Outcomes: HotMobile 2020 was held on March 3-4, 2020. Given the accommodation cost, it is expected that the total expenses per student to attend HotMobile 2020, including airfare, will easily exceed $1100. When factoring in the student registration fee, together with the typical travel and lodging costs associated with attending a workshop, will impose a hardship on many students and/or their faculty advisors. Hence, we seek funding to help offset these costs. During this time is when many of the COVID19 travel restrictions began and a number of attendees were not able to attend the conference at the last minute, particularly International attendees. Despite the COVID restrictions, HotMobile 2020 had 17 applicants who attended domestic institutions and received NSF travel grant support. Two (2) of the students were women accounting for 17%. Three (3) of the students were Black or African American (~18%), one (1) of the students was White (5.9%), and thirteen (13) of the students was Asian (76.5%). Sixteen (16) of the students were first time attendees.
